sentences.sentence: One morning, soon after their arrival, as she was sitting with her two elder sisters, she said to Elizabeth:
“Lizzy, I just realized that I never told you about my wedding( 婚礼 ).
You were not here, when I told mamma( 妈妈 ) and the others all about it.
Are not you curious to hear how it happened?”
“Not really,” replied Elizabeth, “I think enough has already been said on that subject.”
“Ha! You are so strange! But I must tell you how it went.
We were married, you know, at St. Clement’s, because Wickham was staying near there.
And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven o’clock.
My uncle and aunt and I were to go together, and the others were to meet us at the church.
Well, just as the carriage came to the door, my uncle was called away on business.
I was so frightened that I did not know what to do, because my uncle was supposed to walk me down the aisle( 走廊 ).
If we were late by more than an hour, we could not be married at all that day.
But luckily he came back again in ten minutes’ time, and then we all set out.
However, I remembered afterward( 之后 ) that if he had been prevented from going, the wedding( 婚礼 ) need not have been delayed, for Mr. Darcy might have done the job as well.”
“Mr. Darcy!” repeated Elizabeth, in complete amazement( 惊讶 ).
“Oh, yes!—he was supposed to come there with Wickham, you know.
But my goodness! I quite forgot! I should not have said even a word about it.
I promised them so faithfully! What will Wickham say? It was supposed to be such a secret!”
“If it was supposed to be secret,” said Jane, “then do not say another word on the subject.
You can trust that I will ask nothing further.”
“Oh! Certainly,” said Elizabeth, although she was burning with curiosity, “we will ask you no more questions.”
“Thank you,” said Lydia, “for if you did, I would certainly tell you everything, and then Wickham would be angry.”
After being given such encouragement to ask, Elizabeth was forced to escape the temptation( 诱惑 ) by running away.
But it was impossible for her to continue in ignorance( 忽视 ) about something so important.
Mr. Darcy had been at her sister’s wedding( 婚礼 ), at the exact place and with the exact people where he would seem least likely to want to go.
She could not stand such suspense( 悬念 ).
Quickly grabbing( 抓 ) a sheet of paper, she wrote a short letter to her aunt.
She asked for an explanation of what Lydia had said, unless there were very good reasons not to tell her, in which case she would have to remain in ignorance( 忽视 ).
“Not that I shall, though,” she said to herself, “if my aunt does not tell me, I shall use whatever tricks I can to find it out.”
Elizabeth was quickly satisfied by receiving an answer to her letter as soon as she possibly could.
Gracechurch Street
Sept. 6.
MY DEAR NIECE,
I have just received your letter, and will spend this whole morning answering it.
I must admit I was surprised by your request for an explanation.
I did not expect it from you, of all people.
Your uncle is as surprised as I am.
He only acted as he did because he was sure that everything was done with your knowledge and approval( 认可 ).
But if you are really innocent and ignorant( 不明白的 ), I must be more explicit( 明确的 ).
Just a few days after you left, your uncle had a very unexpected visitor.
Mr. Darcy came by, and was busy with him several hours.
He came to tell Mr. Gardiner that he had found out where your sister and Mr. Wickham were hiding, and that he had seen and talked with them both.
He had spoken to Wickham several times, and Lydia once.
It seems that he left Derbyshire only one day after we did, and came to town in order to hunt for them.
His claimed motive( 动机 ) was that it was his own fault that Wickham’s worthlessness( 无用 ) had not been so well known as to prevent any young woman from trusting him.
He generously blamed his own mistaken pride, which had prevented him from exposing( 揭露 ) his private actions to the world.
He said that it was his duty therefore, to remedy( 补救 ) an evil( 坏事 ) which had been brought on by himself.
If he had another motive( 动机 ), I am sure it would never disgrace( 使丢脸 ) him.
It took some days for him to discover them, but unlike us, he had something to direct his search.

article_info.previous: 思虑再三，Mr. Bennet还是决定亲笔回信，同意这个提议。但是财产划分和如何偿还舅舅的两大难题又摆在他们的面前。Lydia和Wickham的婚礼就这样举行了，Lydia欢呼雀跃，到处炫耀自己成为了Wickham夫人。Elizabeth怏怏不乐，终于意识到Darcy是自己的意中人，但是由于这场婚礼，深知结良缘再无可能。
article_info.share_words: He generously blamed his own mistaken pride, which had prevented him from exposing his private actions to the world.

question.cn: Elizabeth对于Lydia的婚礼态度是怎样的？
question.en: What was Elizabeth's attitude towards Lydia's wedding?

options.cn: 她非常感兴趣并且想知道每一个细节。
options.en: She was quite interested in it and wanted to know every detail of it.
She was not curious about it.

options.cn: 她表现出了很大的热情。
options.en: She showed great passion to it.

analysis: 文中Elizabeth说道：“ I think enough has already been said on that subject.”由此可知正确选项为B。

question.cn: Lydia婚礼上的什么消息使Elizabeth感到大吃一惊？
question.en: What news surprised Elizabeth a lot about  Lydia's wedding?

options.en: That Mr. Darcy was present at the wedding.
That Mr. Wickham was not willing to marry Lydia at the beginning.
That Lydia refused to marry Mr. Wickham at the beginning.

analysis: 文中提到：“ Mr. Darcy had been at her sister's wedding, at the exact place, and with the exact people where he would seem least likely to want to go. ”可知选择A。

question.cn: Mrs. Gardiner的信中提到是最初是谁率先找到了Lydia和Wickham?
question.en: Who found Lydia and Wickham originally according to Mrs. Gardiner's letter?

analysis: 文中提到：“ He came to tell Mr. Gardiner that he had found where your sister and Mr. Wickham were hiding…”可知选择B。
